comments.commentBody:
Why? Who really cares. Find ways to reverse the trend.

We want it all, and we want it now. So take it.

Embrace the idea of having children at a younger age, early 20s. Work towards that vision - backwards engineering, like Vic Gundrota's take on product design. Start with the demo of how the finished product should work.

Some ideas of what we need:
* rethink education > it's all wrong. Too much emphasis on cognitive development, too little on intuition/emotional development. It costs way too much money and time. I say, aim at real case based learning from the start of school. Meaning, invite child labour in thru the back door, but this time, let the child decide what to do and how. Validate with real value. That's how kids learn - hearts and bellies, feet and hands. Help them learn how to create the value they need.
* rethink childcare options. I vote "community childcare," organised and staffed largely by parents themselves (ouderparticipatiecreche in Holland). I want to be involved in the daily activities and raising of my child, not park them in the early, most tender years of their life.
* rethink money. What do you really need in life? How could you get that, does money come in at all?
* role models. Roll out the read carpet for those who consciously chose to have children at an early age. I know they're out there. Invite them out to honour them and learn their lessons.

I hope our kids will start early on. Late mom, early grandma? I got their back, and will let them know.

Let's do this, mums, dad, grandparents, politicians, entrepreneurs, CEO's, and anyone who cares!

Written by an innovative mom - I wanted to have kids at 23, but didnt settle with my man before 24, and then didn't know it enough to convince him, myself, and just do it, trusting life to work itself out. I needed 10 years for that - our first was born at age 34. No regrets, but the richness of life after having kids... if I 'd known before, I'd known one thing: JUST DO IT

Everyone commenting here just assumes that women stay home with kids if they decide too.
Firstly, living off one salary is simply not realistic for the average American family.
Secondly, even if a family can make it on one salary, it does not mean that the higher salary is being earner by the man. Many men stay at home with children too.
Lastly, there is a general attitude that the husband has no say in whether or not the wife stays home, regardless of the size of his paycheck. Has it ever occurred to people that perhaps many men would not want to be married to a stay at home wife (at least not a long-term one). It changes the dynamics of the marriage. Furthermore, in these days of equality, us women should be contributing to household finances (just as men should be contributing to household chores and childcare). If working at an office is so horrible, its not fair to make the men put up with it alone.

I'm sorry, I missed the part where these "credibility-crushing" accusations against the accuser actually did anything to harm her credibility, or the credibility of her accusation? Since when does having loan debt mean you can't be the victim of sexual assault?
The frenzy on either side is striking. Why can't they both be liars?

As expected with all this hired gun representation and reality of the jurisprudence in this country, the innocence or guilt is irrelevant. The prosecutors as usual from the start can indict a ham sandwich and these grand juries along with the presiding judges just go along for the ride.

Obviously the prosecutors failed to do their home work and were gun ho for self interests and self righteousness. The credibility of the accuser in this case her word against his is what matters.

There is no case and the Manhattan district attorney may wind up with a huge liability of a wrongful indictment and accusation.

In the end the public will never know what really did happen. No jury will buy the testimony of an witness that has credibility issues, was laundering drug money and has convicted drug dealers felon as associates. What ever happened to that attorney Shapiro who represented this women with such a dubious record and her equally dubious application seeking refuge in this country. Now her application will prove to be false and construed and she will be subject to deportation.

@ Rs in Georgia

I don't know what happened in this case. But your statement "A man of Strauss-Kahn's statue usually doesn't indulge himself during a visit to NY City," indicating that rape is an indulgence, is unbelievable. Rape is a crime, not an indulgence--and making a statement like this changes how we discuss and think about these events.
It was clear from the beginning that he was set up. What a shame! Poor guy. Why do we rush to make a judgment so fast?

Some people seem to support fracking based on the belief that, if strictly regulated, it can be safely implemented. If their view is correct, then why did the oil and gas industry press for fracking's exemption from the Safe Drinking Water Act and other landmark federal environmental protections? That went wrong, they may concede, but now the industry is doing it right? If so, how do you explain the ongoing devastation in the shale regions of Pennsylvania?  Where in this country is fracking NOT destroying health and environment?  Do you recall Ian Urbina's New York Times revelations about fracking-caused radioactivity in Pennsylvania drinking water--and the lax regulation and enforcement behind it?  Do you think the experts know how far fracking-tainted water can travel underground?  Whether or not we can count on New York's DEC to enforce the new flowback containment requirements, too little is known about the flow behavior of all the tainted water left underground. It is poisoned with chemicals that are toxic in parts per trillion. And all water associated with fracking is permanently removed from the hydrological cycle--an unprecedented occurrence in our increasingly drought-prone world. Pampered energy companies are reaping the profits of this destruction, selling much of the gas overseas. They are not patriots lessening our dependence on foreign oil; they do laugh all the way to the bank.

No. 148 Gloria helped me to understand the situation here. I can appreciate the frustration many people feel. I felt it too, until I read Gloria's explanation. There is only one thing we can be sure of in the case: the only people who know what really trainspired in that hotel room are the accuser and the accused. By calling into question her ability to be truthful, (remember folks, you can't just pick and choose when you want to tell the truth and when you want to lie), her credibility in this case has been called into question. And with that, we have a stalemate. The trial would end in a hung juty because there is no way we can know whether or not she is telling the truth. She says, he raped her. He says he didn't. There is no way anyone without actually witnessing the encounter firsthand, can reasonably know who is telling the truth. Since the prosecutors cannot provide any proof of rape, (she calls it rape;he calls it consensual). The word, rape, is a loaded word so much so, I feel myself as if this guy is getting away with something, but that is a bias I have and not rooted in the contest being waged here. The truth, as some readers have asutely noted, is impossible for any of us to know. The case has reached a stalemate. So it is over.

Obviously the public never had all the evidence, so how could we know if DSK was really guilty as charged? At the same time, many comments on the NYT blog suggested that people had already made up their mind's as to DSK's culpability. Without benefit of a real trial or all the evidence, this seemed somewhat unwise. If the Prosecutor's office is suddenly pulling back this dramatically, there may well be some really damning evidence to support the change of position.

As the case against DSK deteriorates I am thinking of that local state senator who on a knee jerk, introduced a bill to give all hotel maids high tech alarm systems. I don't know the status of this waste of time but imagine if it had or does go through. I'd be thinking of that guy each time I pay more when I check in to a hotel in NYC. For what? Nothing! Maybe he should resign.

Shame on all the leftist elitists for their brazen attempt to make a member of the money class look like one of their worst stereotypes.

I hope that DSK flies back to Paris on Obama's new symbol of corporatism; the corporate jet! You go guy!

Good attorneys. That's what someone who pays $250,000 a month for house arrest can do. The woman is linked to an incarcerated man--so its open season.It is a shame that her fiance is a convict. I don't think that means she can be raped with impunity--but if you are raped and you are not perfect, I guess its ok.

Mr Vance should be disbarred and dismissed with the same fanfare he managed to create in destroying a man who was a legend in France.

This does not help the American image in the world of reckless cowboys -- how can this country now repair the perceptions that its entire justice system is not a circus ??

The public, media, NYPD, prosecutors and the defense were too quick to make judgments on this case.  Immediately, DSK was painted as a philandering politician with money and connections while the woman was painted as a helpless single-mother immigrant.  Lesson: figure out the facts before you start ruining people’s lives.  An embarrassment for the public, media, NYPD, prosecutors and the defense.

It will be more interesting to see how many of these women end up having children. It 's only after these women are past their childbearing years that we will know if this about delay or denial of the choice to be a parent. If it's the former, it is about something totally different than if it's that latter.
Good post- thanks.

Brian (#47): I appreciate your responding to clarify your position. You clearly believe that the geese must be culled. A recitation of facts about slow turtles and fast geese, however, does nothing to clarify the terms of debate, which is at root a conflict between moral perspectives that centers on how we interact with the rest of our ecosystem.

You imply that people who dislike the culls are mawkish sentimentalists. The NYMag article quotes the president of the Humane Society as agreeing that there is a problem (and even helping with the egg-addling) but also criticizing the USDA for being historically inclined to kill animals. He is correct on both counts. He then notes a successful relocation program that took place with gulls near JFK in the 90’s.

Here are some facts from the same article, which I have not bothered to check: in 2010, the geese numbered ~ 257,000 in NY state. 15,000-20,000 Canada geese currently live year-round in the metro region. Over the past three decades, there have been “as many as” 315 bird-plane collisions each year. The USDA decided, by methods not described, that a mere 5000 birds is an “acceptable” number. If they mean to leave 5000 in NY state, that’s quite a massacre they propose; if they mean only in the metro area, that’s still a significant cull. The article doesn’t mention the number of planes that fly over the city, but 300 collisions actually isn’t much—and even if you kill birds that are nesting near the airport, the famous Sullenberger landing in the Hudson River was forced by _migrating_ geese. It is valid to ask whether culling birds on Riker’s Island and Prospect Park is going to do much to reduce an already-low risk (a report covering 1912-2002 estimated that bird strikes cause 1 human death per 1 billion flying hours; needless to say, the birds come out much worse).

I will post the rest of my reply at http://wwwmiscellaneousmusings.blogspot.com/

Connecticut's experience with trying to appease public worker unions validates the approach taken by the Republican governors in New Jersey, Wisconsin, Ohio, Florida and Maine. Public workers should not have any rights to collective bargaining against taxpayers. Indeed, public workers should be employees at will subject to termination whenever that is in the best interests of their employer - just as employees in the private sector.

The Michigan Income Tax form offers choices (A) Affirm that one made no on-line tax-free purchases, (B) State the total spent on such purchases and then add the tax on that to one's remittance to the state, or (C) Let the state estimate, on the basis of the Adjusted Gross Income, how much one has purchased tax free... and then add the tax on that amount to the remittance to the state.
One could choose (A) but then would become extremely vulnerable to tax audits that explored credit card and paypal transactions ---- a few well-publicized prosecutions would provide a strong deterrent to choice A; I'd guess that most of the citizens of Michigan would opt for choice (C).
Because this tax hit comes only once per year, our policy does little to cancel the apparent price advantage of Amazon since sales tax still does not appear on its invoices for sales to Michigan people. The brick&mortar stores are still at a significant disadvantage.

Much to my dismay, the latest version of Eudora (8) no longer contains the Bcc: option.  I have absolutely no idea why they would make a change that is so idiotic.  It drives me nuts, and I often send out apologies with my emails for the long address lists.

#14- Ella, I'm a physician with 15+ years of experience, and my specialty is in an already underserved field. (Therefore, according to Dr. Sibert, I should be ashamed that I only work part time.) I feel very lucky to have a job which I feel is meaningful, serves society, and allows flexibility. I feel actually very fortunate. To put this in perspective, though, the hardest part of my training took up my entire 20's and early 30's. I put off marrying and having a family because I could not juggle working 100+ hour weeks with anything else. It was really tough. I stuck with it, paid my dues, had lots of good luck, allowed a couple of years of experience to get under my belt, didn't give up on developing my personal life when I finally got a breather, and now w/. small kids, finally am reaping the reward. It's still not a complete balance, and it is stressful, but I feel that there is  much richness and depth in what I do professionally. The same as what I do at home.

"Much to my dismay, the latest version of Eudora (8) no longer contains the Bcc: option."

jim, If it's true Eudora no longer contains the BCC option, (possibly it's hidden in an unfamiliar new place), why continue to use it? Long address lists are not only inconvenient for your contacts, but expose their e-mail addresses to bad guys.
Another elite walks away from a crime that would send a working man to prison for 5-10 years.  Classic case of smearing the victim. $$$ buys you influence, silence and freedom.

I finished it ... I finished it by myself. I hated ENTO though. Tried to make ECTO and ENDO work way too long.

ARKANSAS was my way in too.

And who on earth knows these men's toiletries? Bryllcreem even ...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jRcRIbExrfg spells 46A differently.

BUT ... check the trademark records:

http://tess2.uspto.gov/bin/showfield?f=doc&state=4004:mi965s.2.2

WTG Chris and Will!

This was a wonderful Friday puzzle.

Deb, I always thought Rex's alter ego taught and there is that Prof at 59D. Are you suggesting a mini-theme?

My experience was similar to Steve @1. Haven't decided what to think about this puzzle, so I'm going to sleep on it and see how I feel in the morning. Maybe by then my frustration will have dissolved and my joy will have awakened.
Almost as long in the middle as supercalifagilisticetcetcetc
